Title: probability mass function of sum of two independent geometric random variables
Content:
How could it be proved that the probability mass function of X + Y, where X and Y are independent random variables each geometrically distributed with parameter p; i.e. $p_X(n)=p_Y(n)=\left\{\begin{matrix}
p(1-p)^{n-1} & n=1,2,...\\ 
0 & otherwise
\end{matrix}\right.$ equals to $\mathbf{P_{X+Y}(n)= \color{Red}{(n-1)}\ p^2(1-p)^{n-2}}$ Using convolution I get $\mathbf{P(X+Y=n)=\sum_{n}^{k=0} Pr(X=k)*Pr(Y=n-k) =\sum_{k=1}^n p_X (1-p_x)^{k-1} p_Y(1-p_Y)^{n-k-1}}$ as $p=p_X=p_Y$  it reduces to $\mathbf{P(X+Y=n)=\sum_{k=1}^n p^2(1-p)^{n-2}}$ is this a correct way? I am stuck here, I don't know how to get the final formula.I miss some transition in order to get the (n-1).
AcceptedAnswer:
Since $X, Y \geq 1$, the summation should run over $k = 1,2, \dots, n-1$.  Using this your convolution becomes \begin{eqnarray*} P(X+Y = n) &=& \sum_{k=1}^{n-1} p^2(1-p)^{n-2} \\
& = & p^2(1-p)^{n-2}\sum_{k=1}^{n-1} 1 \\
& = & p^2(1-p)^{n-2}(n-1) .
\end{eqnarray*}

Each term in the sum is p(1-p)^{k-1} * p(1-p)^{(n - k) - 1} = p²(1-p)^{k - 1 + n - k - 1} = p²(1-p)^{n - 2}. 

So each term in the sum is p²(1-p)^{n - 2}, which is independent of k. Therefore, the sum becomes p²(1-p)^{n - 2} multiplied by the number of terms in the summation. 

The summation goes from k=1 to k=n-1, which is (n - 1) terms. Therefore, the total sum is (n - 1) * p²(1-p)^{n - 2}, which is the desired result.
